questions.question: My child likes to draw pictures or doodles in her/his notes.
My child remembers things better when she/he sees pictures or diagrams.
It helps my child to picture something in her/his mind to remember it.
My child remembers things better when she/he hears them spoken aloud.
My child finds it helpful to listen to explanations or stories.
My child pays more attention when a teacher talks rather than uses pictures.
My child finds it easiest to remember things when she/he writes them down.
My child prefers to read instructions or notes to help him/her learn.
My child likes making lists or taking notes to remember things.
My child understands better when she/he does hands-on activities.
My child remembers things better when she/he can touch or move around.
My child gets restless if she/he has to sit still for too long.

errors.missingAnswer: You missed question {number}. Please answer it before submitting.

definitions.Visual: You understand and retain information best when it's presented through images, diagrams, charts, or visual aids. Seeing concepts laid out visually helps you grasp and remember them more easily.
definitions.Auditory: You learn best by listening. Hearing information, whether through lectures, discussions, or audio recordings, helps you absorb and process knowledge effectively.
definitions.Verbal: You excel in learning through words. Reading, writing, and engaging in conversations help you understand and remember information more effectively.
definitions.Kinesthetic: You understand and retain information through hands-on activities and movement. You prefer learning by doing, engaging with physical tasks or experiences to solidify your understanding.
